snippet: Russians took to the streets last month because they feel like their country has no use for them - which means they'll probably be out there again soon.
abstract: Russians took to the streets last month because they feel like their country has no use for them - which means they'll probably be out there again soon.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW - After New Year's - the biggest traditional family holiday of the year - Russia descends into an odd, sleepy state for 10 days. Most businesses go on vacation, Moscow's hellish traffic temporarily evaporates, and Russians spend their days in that hazy state between hangover and drink, either at their snowed-in dachas or on warmer shores. A couple of days after Orthodox Christmas on Jan. 7, they will emerge from hibernation and stumble into work, dazed by the prospect of three more months of winter.
